trial_identification.studytitle: Angiotensin Converting Enzyme (ACE) Inhibition and Peripheral Arterial Disease
trial_identification.scientifictitle: ACE Inhibition; A Potential New Therapy for Peripheral Arterial Disease

conditioncode.conditioncode2: Diseases of the vasculature and circulation including the lymphatic system

interventions.interventions:
Treatment: drugs - Ramipril or matching placebo
Treatment: drugs: Ramipril or matching placebo 10 mg Ramipril or matching placebo once daily for 6 months

eligibility.inclusivecriteria:
- Ankle brachial index of <0.9 in at least one leg
- History of intermittent claudication (unilateral or bilateral)
- A stable medication regimen for at least 6 months
eligibility.exclusivecriteria:
- Limiting coronary artery disease
- Renal failure (serum creatinine > 0.20 mmol/L)
- Current treatment or treatment within the previous 6 months with ACE inhibitors or angiotensin II receptor antagonists

ethicsAndSummary.summary: Leg pain caused by peripheral arterial disease (PAD) can severely impede walking ability. Our preliminary findings indicate that the drug ramipril is much more effective in improving walking ability than current therapies. To be accepted as a new treatment for PAD these findings require validation in a much larger clinical trial.We propose to examine the effects of ramipril therapy for 6 months in a randomized, controlled trial of patients with PAD. If positive, this study will identify ramipril as a potential new therapy for PAD.
ethicsAndSummary.publication: Ahimastos AA, Lawler A, Reid CM, Blombery PA, Kingwell BA.
